original_data.question: A 45-year-old Caucasian male presents to a gastroenterologist complaining of heartburn and difficulty swallowing. He recalls that he has been told by his primary care physician that he suffers from gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The gastroenterologist decides to perform an upper endoscopy with biopsy. Which of the following findings would be consistent with Barrett's esophagus?

options.A: Presence of Paneth cells in the lower esophagus
options.C: A small region of red, velvet-like mucosa in the lower esophagus

model_response:
The presence of columnar epithelium in the esophagus is a metaplastic change secondary to GERD. The presence of Paneth cells in the lower esophagus would be incorrect because Paneth cells are normally found in the basal poion of the small intestine. The other choices are not associated with Barrett's esophagus.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A group distinguished by classification according to physical features. This group, also called Europoid, centers around the Mediterranean Sea but includes other parts of Europe. (from Winick: Dictionary of Anthropology, 1972; American Heritage Dictionary, 2d College ed)
A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Physicians who specialize in treating diseases of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
Substernal pain or burning sensation, usually associated with regurgitation of gastric juice into the esophagus.

Difficulty in SWALLOWING which may result from neuromuscular disorder or mechanical obstruction. Dysphagia is classified into two distinct types: oropharyngeal dysphagia due to malfunction of the PHARYNX and UPPER ESOPHAGEAL SPHINCTER; and esophageal dysphagia due to malfunction of the ESOPHAGUS.
Providers of initial care for patients. These PHYSICIANS refer patients when appropriate for secondary or specialist care.
State of severe distress associated with events that threaten the intactness of the person, can be physical, mental, or emotional.
Retrograde flow of gastric juice (GASTRIC ACID) and/or duodenal contents (BILE ACIDS; PANCREATIC JUICE) into the distal ESOPHAGUS, commonly due to incompetence of the LOWER ESOPHAGEAL SPHINCTER.
Retrograde flow of gastric juice (GASTRIC ACID) and/or duodenal contents (BILE ACIDS; PANCREATIC JUICE) into the distal ESOPHAGUS, commonly due to incompetence of the LOWER ESOPHAGEAL SPHINCTER.
Physicians who specialize in treating diseases of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM.
An endoscopic procedure that visualizes the upper part of the gastrointestinal tract up to the duodenum.
Removal and pathologic examination of specimens from the living body.
Marked by a reasonable or logical relation of parts and holding together as a harmonious or credible whole.

A condition with damage to the lining of the lower ESOPHAGUS resulting from chronic acid reflux (ESOPHAGITIS, REFLUX). Through the process of metaplasia, the squamous cells are replaced by a columnar epithelium with cells resembling those of the INTESTINE or the salmon-pink mucosa of the STOMACH. Barrett's columnar epithelium is a marker for severe reflux and precursor to ADENOCARCINOMA of the esophagus.
